page.title: 02LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: The Chartist Estate of Snig's End was built in 1848 on the border between the parishes of Corse and Staunton by Fergus O'Connor. It is of considerable interest to social historians. 80 single storey houses were built of good materials. Every house had two bedrooms, a living room, kitchen, skullery, dairy and well. Each house had a holding of 2-4 acres planted with fruit trees and cash crops but sadly marketing was poor and the original intention of helping working people to get not only the vote but agricultural holdings did not succeed. Today about 60 of the houses still exist. Most no longer have very much land but two still provide a living. The Chartist Meeting House is now a pub. Staunton Church has a good Jacobean monument and 15th Century barrel vaulting in the North Aisle.
